title: 109_s1691
content:
The Act titled "Home School Non-Discrimination Act of 2005" is cited as such. Key findings are outlined in Section 2. The Act "Home School Non-Discrimination Act of 2005" outlines key findings affirming parents' right to direct their children's education, highlighting the effectiveness of home education in academic success and socialization skills. Young people educated at home are proving to be competent citizens in postsecondary education and the workplace, contributing positively to education in the United States. Several laws regarding private home education need clarification on how they treat students educated at home according to State law, as the United States Constitution prohibits Federal control of homeschooling. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS: Congress recognizes private home education as a positive contribution to the United States and supports parents who choose this alternative education within the framework of the Constitution.

SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF HIGHER EDUCATION ACT: Amendments clarify institutional and student eligibility under the Higher Education Act of 1965, ensuring compliance with secondary education standards. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF ABSENCE OF CONSENT FOR INITIAL EVALUATION UNDER THE INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES EDUCATION ACT. Section 614(a)(1)(D)(ii)(I) of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to allow a local educational agency to conduct an initial evaluation of a child using specified procedures if the child is enrolled in or seeking enrollment in a public school. The amendment clarifies that expenses for students privately educated at home under State law can be covered by a Coverdell Education Savings Account. This applies to home schools providing elementary or secondary education recognized as such under State law. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Clarification of Section 444 of the General Education Provisions Act regarding publicly held records of students privately educated at home under State law. Section 444 of the General Education Provisions Act is amended to specify that for students in non-public education, including those educated at home or in private schools according to State law, directory information cannot be released without parental consent. Additionally, the amendment clarifies that this provision applies to non-public school students, including those educated at home or in private schools as permitted by State law. The General Education Provisions Act is amended to protect the privacy of non-public school students' education records and personally identifiable information. Organizations conducting studies for educational agencies must ensure that personal identification of students and parents is not possible by anyone outside the organization. Education records and personally identifiable information must be destroyed when no longer needed, and for non-public school students, written consent from parents is required for release. SEC. 8 amends the Higher Education Act to clarify eligibility for the Robert C. Byrd Honors Scholarship Program for students privately educated at home under State law. SEC. 9 clarifies the Fair Labor Standards Act as applied to these students. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to extend permissible employment hours for home-schooled students aged 14-16 beyond those of traditional public school students. Additionally, there is a provision for recruitment and enlistment of home-schooled students in the Armed Forces. The policy for recruitment and enlistment of home-schooled students in the Armed Forces must be prescribed by the Secretary concerned, with uniformity across all branches ensured by the Secretary of Defense. The policy should include identifying home-schooled graduates for recruitment, and providing Tier I status with no practical limit. Home-schooled graduates are exempt from the requirement of a secondary school diploma for enlistment in the Armed Forces. To be identified as a home-schooled graduate, they must score 50 or above on the Armed Forces Qualification Test and provide a signed notice of intent form that complies with state laws. Home-schooled graduates seeking to enlist in the Armed Forces must provide a home school certificate or diploma from a parent, guardian, or national curriculum provider. They also need to submit a transcript with enrollment and graduation dates, curriculum type, and successful completion of the last academic year. Home-schooled graduates enlisting in the Armed Forces must submit a notice of intent form, use a curriculum closely resembling traditional schools, and provide third-party verification of their home school status. The term "Secretary concerned" is defined in section 101(a)(9) of title 10, United States Code.
